newsitem.title: USA: New York passenger sues TWA over missed flight.
newsitem.headline: New York passenger sues TWA over missed flight.

text.p: A New York City man has filed a $6.5 million lawsuit against Trans World Airlines, claiming the airline had him removed from a flight and kept him from saying farewell to his dying father in Israel.
Security guards removed Reouven Barzilai, a jazz club owner, from a TWA flight in a dispute over smoking, he said Tuesday.
"Because of TWA's actions, by the time I reached my father he was already in a coma and I could no longer talk to him," Barzilai said.

Barzilai, a smoker, said he booked a seat on TWA Flight 884 on Jan. 22 from New York's Kennedy International Airport because he believed it was a smoking flight. But as he boarded, he said TWA announced smoking would not be permitted.

Barzilai's attorney Michael Wolin said an attendent asked his client to leave the plane and called airport security when he refused. "He never smoked on the plane, he never created a disturbance. He's a very quiet man," the lawyer said.
Wolin said Barzalai was charged with criminal trespass and disorderly conduct. A day later, a Queens Criminal Court judge dismissed the case, the lawyer said.
TWA spokesman John McDonald said from the airline's St. Louis headquarters, said, "He has never complained directly to the airline regarding his allegations."
"Further, TWA has not yet received the lawsuit nor has had time to review it," he added.
In the lawsuit, filed in Manhattan Supreme Court last week, Barzilai is seeking $1.5 million in compensatory damages and $5 million in punitive damages.
